I think Bernenke is doing exactly what is needed. The Fed is keeping things on a steady course.

The big complaint is that the low interest rates are keeping CD and savings rates too low. They always have been, they never were good investments for retirement.
The rates were high in the 80s and 90s, but that was an anomaly, yet buyers of CDs expected that to continue.

Over the years the low rates on them hardly kept up with inflation and in most cases lost value because of it. Buy good equities from well established companies, collect the dividends and watch the stock increase in value at the same time.

If it had not been for the Fed, we would all be in the soup line. Well, not all of course, but at least 25% would be, and the rest of us would be paying for it. Read "Lords Of Finance: the Bankers That Broke The World."

As we learn in the most fundamental civics class, there is no right to scream "Fire!" in a crowded theater.  Your right to swing your fist ends at my nose.  The right to bear arms should end with massacred children, and prevent ownership of assault and semi-automatic weapons and ammunition.

We regularly apply the kinds of tests you describe to gun ownership: guns are among the most heavily regulated commodities we tolerate in our society.You can't lawfully buy or keep one if you're a former felon, a known drug abuser or have been diagnosed with many mental disorders. We don't restrict ownership of cars like that, with which you could do pretty serious damage if you were so minded; or knives, for that matter, or fertilizer a la Timothy McVeigh.

People like semi-automatic weapons, which are not "machine guns"; and they have their own reasons for liking them that are actually none of your business, or mine either for that matter; but that clearly are lawful, protected by the constitution, and here to stay.

Your certainty in your moral superiority over the guy who gets a kick out of mowing down beer bottles with a "machine gun" (that you can't actually buy lawfully) really doesn't require a serious response.

Our courts have shown time and again that there are no absolute rights in this country. Even our most precious right, the right to free speech, can be limited when exercise of it would cause undo harm to others. So, why is it that we are unwilling to apply the same test to the second amendment?

I'm personally not asking for a total gun ban. However, we should seriously consider banning semi-automatic weapons of any kind... and, then, offer a government sponsored buy-back program to reimburse those who must turn in their weapons.

For those who swear they'll protect their precious 2nd amendment freedoms with their lives? Where were they when their government attacked many, more fundamental freedoms with the 'Patriot' Act? The right to legal representation and protection from incarceration without representation just aren't as much fun as mowing down beer bottles with a machine gun.

"There were 13 cases of thyroid cancer, 7 more than expected, and 67 cases of prostate cancer, 20 more than expected."

The absolute number of cancers is extremely small. Even if we could agree that anyone diagnosed with these cancers should be treated and compensated in some fashion because of their first responder/hero status, this does not imply that their cancers are attributable to WTC exposure. At the very least, as the study implies, we cannot identify which, if any, cancers are attributable to WTC exposure.

How we compensate people and how we determine etiology of disease are two distinct issues. It just so happens that we tend to compensate sick people, over and above the standard medical treatments that are provided when not engaged in a first responder endeavor, by determining that the first responder/heroic activity was the cause of the disease. If not ill, or if ill but not a first responder/hero, or just a plain Joe Schmoe who happened to be waiting tables in the WTC, then you get nothing special.

Let's talk about another aspect of mental health.

I've heard that the shooter's mother owned the weapons because she believed an economic collapse was coming. Apparently, she thought the best procedure wasn't, say, political activity on improving the economy but preparing to blast the neighbors if they came after her food.

Yes, her son did the shooting. But it's striking that his actions also reflected exaggerated perceptions, hostility, inability to imagine constructive solutions, anger and an accompanying devaluing of others, and a feeling against his neighbors rather than feeling in it together.

I've been very disturbed at the increasing spread of hostility, delusion, and every-man-for-himself-ism in many categories—from calling our president a Kenyan Socialist Muslim without a birth certificate, to angry insistence that the poor or unemployed are simply well-to-do moochers, to the idea that an international treaty on the rights of the disabled based on our law is a wormhole for a UN takeover.

It's easy to label the shooter as "mentally ill"—after all, any person who commits a massacre can, by definition, be called that. But there is a related and more widespread strain of irrationality and anger that we politely pass over every day as mere "political differences".

Meanwhile the rest of the world is asking, "What is wrong with you people that you can't get reasonable gun control/national health care/etc.?!"

They see it more clearly than we do.
